subject: Re: [junit] Test and test case dependencies
msgSnippet: When B calls C, is B s method trivial? See the JUnit FAQ for details on what I mean by that. If B s method is trivial, then testing B only tests C and nothing
messageBody:
When B calls C, is B's method trivial? See the JUnit FAQ for details on what I mean by that. If B's method is trivial, then testing B only tests C and nothing else, so I wouldn't bother writing the test. If B's method takes parameters and passes them to C, then B's method still cannot break: only the methods that call B's method and C could break, so test those.

I would use the same approach for the relationship between A and B.

If B's method is not trivial, then as soon as you feel the pain of duplicated tests mock the behavior in C that B calls and use that mock behavior in the test. This allows you to test B in isolation from any defects in C.

I hope this helps.

>So said Jonathan Oddy on 4/25/2003 --------------------
>I understand that in general we want to write tests and test cases that are
>not dependent upon each other so that an earlier failing(?) test doesn't
>set
>state of the underlying object(s) to prejudice later tests. Okay fine, but
>I was wondering how people solve/resolve the following type of dependency.
>
>
>If I have three classes A, B and C where A delegates some functionality to
>B
>which delegates to C. During my implementation and unit testing I write
>tests for C then implement the desired functionality in C. I then repeat
>the process for B and A, okay fine. But now I have an implied unit test
>dependency don't I? So when running my tests as a suite I really want my
>test cases to run in the order C, B, A and never any other order because if
>the defect is in C then I want to know about it from C and not from A or B.
>
>
>I am currently implementing a small library that does a lot of this style
>of
>delegation, and being reasonably new to JUnit I wondered how other people
>work round this issue especially since those nice Eclipse people provide a
>helpful "run all tests in a package option".
>
>Thanks inadnavce
>
